CNNâ€™s Christy Choi and Julia Chatterley contributed to this report. The Emmys went for the gold Sunday night. Jane Lynch and Brendan Hunt â€” who played coaches on â€œGleeâ€ and â€œTed Lasso,â€ respectively â€” presented the best directing for a drama award and had some fun while they were at it, appearing in a locker room set and cracking some jokes. Lynch, who also played Sue Sylvester on â€œGlee,â€ teased Hunt that his role as Coach Beard on â€œTed Lassoâ€ was just an assistant coach, while she was a head coach. They were joined on stage by several Olympic athletes, including Olympic gymnast Stephen Nedoroscik, who captured hearts this summer as the â€œClark Kentâ€ of pommel horse. The FX restaurant dramedy â€œThe Bearâ€ is having a very strong night, as expected. It just picked up another Emmy, this time recognizing Christopher Storer for best directing in a comedy series. Season two of â€œThe Bearâ€ produced some of the most memorable episodes in the seriesâ€™ history, with the cameo-heavy midseason Christmas episode â€œFishes,â€ earning Storer the win tonight. The episode â€” a moving portrait of family trauma â€” generated buzz with its ensemble of guest stars, including Jamie Lee Curtis, Bob Odenkirk, Sarah Paulson, John Mulaney and Jon Bernthal.  Welcome back to the Fonz. The man who played that beloved character, Henry Winkler, reunited with his â€œHappy Daysâ€ costar, Ron Howard, for a little bit of throwback love for the popular series. The pair came together to present an award, but also to remind us all of how much we enjoyed the wholesome show in which Howard started out playing teen Richie Cunningham and introduced the world to his friends and family. â€œHappy Daysâ€ ran over the course of 11 seasons from 1974 to 1984, and won one Primetime Emmy for film editing in 1978. The show enjoyed several other Emmy nominations, including three for Henry Winkler for playing Arthur â€œThe Fonzâ€ Fonzarelli. â€œHappy Daysâ€ firmly put Winkler on the showbiz map, as it did Howard. The Oscar-winning director got his start playing Richie Cunningham on the series. â€œHappy Daysâ€ also led to popular spinoff series including â€œJoanie Loves Chachiâ€ (1982â€“83), â€œLaverne and Shirleyâ€ (1976â€“83), and â€œMork and Mindyâ€ (1978â€“82). The show also helped make the phrase â€œjump the sharkâ€ a thing after Winklerâ€™s character did just that as the series waned in popularity towards the end. The Fonz literally jumped a shark on the show. Richard Gadd took home the Emmy award for outstanding writing for a limited series, anthology or movie. Gadd marked the moment by making a heartfelt speech, reflecting on his personal experience to offer up inspiration for those going through a hard time. A twisty and engrossing tale involving stalking, grooming, abuse and artistic license, â€œBaby Reindeerâ€ was a sensation when it debuted and has since remained a focus of attention, with some of the real-life players behind it disputing the storyâ€™s veracity. Lawsuit context: The series is actually the subject of a lawsuit. Netflix said in June that it would fight a multimillion-dollar claim for damages brought by a Scottish woman who alleges she was defamed by the hit show and its portrayal of a female stalker.  Fiona Harvey is seeking a jury trial and damages totaling $170 million for â€œmental anguish, loss of enjoyment of life and loss of business,â€ according to a complaint filed in the District Court for the Central District of California. The document alleges that the defendants and Gadd told the â€œbiggest lie in television historyâ€ by claiming the story is true. For his part, Gadd previously told UK newspaper The Guardian the story is â€œvery emotionally trueâ€ but that he wanted the series to exist as a piece of art and protect the identities of those involved. His repeated requests, however, for viewers to cease trying to find out the real-life identities of the figures in his story went unheard. In a statement to CNN, a spokesperson for Netflix said, â€œWe intend to defend this matter vigorously and to stand by Richard Gaddâ€™s right to tell his story.â€ CNNâ€™s Dan Heching and Hilary Whiteman contributed reporting. Actors Mindy Kaling, Zach Braff and Mekhi Phifer, who have all played TV doctors, appeared on stage to present the award for outstanding writing for a drama series. Phifer, who played a doctor on the hit NBC medical drama â€œER,â€ said he was â€œso honoredâ€ to play a doctor on the show and that he was inspired by all of the physicians heâ€™s known.  Kaling starred as an OB/GYN on her namesake series â€œThe Mindy Project,â€ and said she was inspired to play a doctor because of her mother, who was also an OB/GYN.  Braff, however, didnâ€™t have as moving of a statement when it came to sharing the inspiration behind playing his beloved role as a doctor on the long-running sitcom â€œScrubs.â€  â€œI was inspired to not live like that anymore,â€ Braff joked.   Lamorne Morris takes home the Emmy for outstanding supporting actor in a limited series or TV movie for his role on â€œFargo.â€ Morris thanked God, his mother, daughter, cast, the categoryâ€™s other nominees as well as FX and Hulu while accepting his award. â€œOh my god Iâ€™m forgetting so many people,â€ he said, adding that he will thank those he didnâ€™t mention in his speech later, on his podcast. A fan-adored anthology crime series conceived from the Oscar-winning 1996 film of the same name, â€œFargoâ€™sâ€ fifth season is in the mix this year with 15 Primetime Emmy nods, having previously won six statuettes in years past. CNNâ€™s Dan Heching contributed reporting. The Emmy for outstanding talk series is awarded to â€œThe Daily Show,â€ and longtime host John Stewart is up on the stage with the rest of the cast. It was the TV momsâ€™ turn when Susan Kelechi Watson, Connie Britton and Meredith Baxter appeared on stage to present the award for comedy writing.  Britton, who famously played a mom on â€œFriday Night Lightsâ€ and â€œWhite Lotus,â€ said that TV moms â€œdo it all,â€ whether that be a country music star (on â€œNashvilleâ€), the head of a â€œhaunted householdâ€ or a school principal.  Kelechi Watson, who played mom Beth Pearson on NBC hit show â€œThis is Us,â€ added that â€œTV moms are no longer one dimensionalâ€¦ We have choices.â€  Kelechi Watson also joked that â€œitâ€™s ok to ask for as much money as a TV dad.â€ Baxter â€” classic TV mom of â€œFamily Tiesâ€ fame â€” also touched on how far TV mom roles have come, saying sheâ€™s thankful â€œwe are way past the days where we couldnâ€™t even say the word â€˜pregnantâ€™ on â€˜I Love Lucy.â€™â€ â€œHacksâ€ earns the award for outstanding writing for a comedy series at the Emmys, and the cast used their acceptance speech to crack a few jokes. Lucia Aniello, Paul W. Downs and Jen Statsky took the award for the episode â€œBulletproof.â€ Itâ€™s the second Emmy win for the â€œHacksâ€ writers in this category. Downs said the trio of writers chose to write about comedy because they were â€œthree weird lonely kids â€” it was the thing that made us feel connected to other people.â€ Statsky and Angelo then playfully corrected Downs, whispering in his ear for him to say they werenâ€™t unpopular. The Max comedy series follows aging stand-up comedian Deborah Vance (played by Jean Smart) who joins forces with the young comedy writer Ava Daniels (played by Hannah Einbinder) to save her act at a casino in Las Vegas. The third season of â€œHacksâ€ finds Vance trying to secure a gig as a late-night host, an opportunity she lost earlier in her career over sexism. While presenting the award for writing for a variety special, â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ vets Maya Rudolph, Kristen Wiig, Bowen Yang and Seth Meyers took the opportunity to poke fun at their current and former boss, â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ creator Lorne Michaels.  Wiig joked that Michaels has â€œlost the Emmyâ€ over 80 times. â€œYou do have value. You are worthy and you are not, and have never been a loser, even though you have lost a lot,â€ Wiig joked, speaking directly to Michaels in the audience.  Rudolph went on to joke that he was â€œrobbedâ€ every single time he lost, while Yang playfully kept pronouncing his last name wrong.  Meyers pointed out that â€œSNLâ€ has won many Emmys, with the long-running sketch comedy series earning over 300 nods with 90 wins. â€œI canâ€™t believe that youâ€™re complaining about this Lorne,â€ Rudolph said. â€œNot to be rude but, grow up!â€ Michaels has won 21 Emmys. Itâ€™s never been uncommon for presenters and winners to make political statements at award shows, but itâ€™s especially prevalent in years when there are major elections. This year, with the presidential election happening in just a few weeks, it was to be expected. Then, just hours before Sunday nightâ€™s Emmy Awards, there was an apparent second assassination attempt against Republican former President Donald Trump. That could make taking jabs at Trump fraught, but a few people have still worked in some form of political statement. Billy Crudup, who won outstanding supporting actor in a drama series for his work on â€œThe Morning Show,â€ shouted out his wife, Naomi Watts. Watts scored a nomination for her performance as Babe Paley in FXâ€™s anthology series â€œFEUD: Capote vs. The Swans.â€ Immigration is a major topic in this yearâ€™s election, particularly over the past week, when the GOP ticket has made increasingly inflammatory remarks about Haitian immigrants in the town of Springfield, Ohio. â€œMurphy Brownâ€ star Candice Bergen drew some laughs by referencing Republican vice presidential nominee JD Vanceâ€™s now infamous comment about â€œchildless cat ladies,â€ after reminiscing about making TV history when her character was attacked in the media by Republican Dan Quayle for a plot line about her being a single mother. Near the top of the show, Selena Gomez also made a reference to the â€œchildless cat ladiesâ€ phenomenon when onstage with her â€œOnly Murders in the Buildingâ€ costars Steve Martin and Martin Short. Jessica Gunning wins outstanding supporting actress in a limited series or TV movie at the 76th Emmy Awards for her twisted role in â€œBaby Reindeer.â€ â€œOh my goodness me. Blinking heckers, thank you so much,â€ Gunning began her remarks. â€œIâ€™m so proud to be a part of â€˜Baby Reindeer,â€™â€ she said. Gunning then gave an emotional nod to creator of and lead actor in the show, Richard Gadd. â€œThank you for trusting me to be your Martha. I will never ever forget her or you,â€ she said. More on the show: â€œBaby Reindeerâ€ is a dramatized version of real events that happened to Gadd. In the show, Gaddâ€™s character, Donny, meets Martha at the pub where he bartends. After he offers her tea on the house, Martha begins to stalk and harass Donny, sabotaging his life. â€œBaby Reindeerâ€ has topped most-watched lists worldwide since its debut in April, generating headlines and speculation about the characters and who inspired them. Gaddâ€™s story is real, but he says the version that appears in his thriller miniseries has been altered for artistic and privacy reasons. CNNâ€™s Sydney Bishop and Hilary Whiteman contributed to this report. The antics continued with hosts Dan and Eugene Levy, who awkwardly introduced actors and TV villains Kathy Bates, Antony Starr and Giancarlo Esposito from opposite sides of the aisle.  â€œI donâ€™t know where my dad is,â€ Dan Levy said, looking around for Eugene Levy, who eventually waved from the â€˜wrongâ€™ aisle.  Dan Levy hilariously admonished his father for getting lost in the theater, to which Eugene Levy replied, â€œI donâ€™t like doing bits in the audience. Never have!â€ Selena Gomez and her boyfriend Benny Blanco, along with Steve Martin and Paul Rudd, were all in the frame laughing along to the lost Levys bit. The Emmy for outstanding reality or competition series goes to â€œThe Traitors.â€ The showâ€™s host Alan Cumming thanked Peacock, the cast and crew as well as his home country, Scotland, while accepting the showâ€™s award. The 10-episode reality competition murder mystery show features 20 contestants â€” 10 of whom have previously appeared on reality programs like â€œSurvivor,â€ â€œBelow Deck,â€ â€œBig Brotherâ€ and â€œThe Real Housewives of Beverly Hillsâ€ â€” competing for $250,000. CNN previously spoke to Cumming about packing for â€œThe Traitors.â€ Read what some of his travel must-haves are here. CNNâ€™s Jolie Kerr contributed reporting. Jean Smart takes home the award for outstanding lead actress in a comedy series for her role in â€œHackâ€ at the Emmys. â€œThank you so, so much,â€ Smart began her speech. â€œItâ€™s very humbling, it really is and I appreciate this because I â€” I just donâ€™t get enough attention,â€ she joked.  Tonightâ€™s win is Smartâ€™s third for â€œHacks.â€ She has won six Primetime Emmys in total. More on the show: The Max comedy series follows aging stand-up comedian Deborah Vance (played by Jean Smart) who joins forces with the young comedy writer Ava Daniels (played by Hannah Einbinder) to save her act at a casino in Las Vegas. In an interview with CNNâ€™s Chris Wallace earlier this year, Smart said she was a bit apprehensive to play opposite Einbinder, a comedian in real life and the daughter of the â€œSaturday Night Liveâ€ original cast member Laraine Newman. Smart said she had never done standup comedy before taking on the role of the brilliant and biting comedian Vance. CNNâ€™s Tori B. Powell and Marianne Garvey contributed to this report. Elizabeth Debicki takes home the Emmy for outstanding supporting actress in a drama series. While accepting her award, Debicki â€” who starred as the â€œPeopleâ€™s Princessâ€ in â€œThe Crownâ€ â€” thanked the showâ€™s creator Peter Morgan, as well as the cast and crew behind the series. This is Debickiâ€™s first Emmy win. More on the show: Netflixâ€™s jewel, â€œThe Crown,â€ has traversed 60 years of world history through the lens of the British monarchy. Debicki played Princess Diana in the most recent season as well as the fifth â€” a performance for which she earned Emmy and Golden Globe nominations. Sheâ€™s previously appeared in the BBCâ€™s crime series â€œThe Night Manager,â€ plus two â€œGuardians of the Galaxyâ€ movies, â€œThe Man from U.N.C.L.Eâ€ and Christopher Nolanâ€™s â€œTenet,â€ among others. CNNâ€™s Alli Rosenbloom and Sandy Thin contributed reporting. The Emmy for outstanding supporting actress in a comedy series goes to Liza ColÃ³n-Zayas for her role in â€œThe Bear.â€ â€œThank for lowering the microphone for me, thank you so much,â€ ColÃ³n-Zayas began her speech. She then noted how her husband told her not to write a speech. â€œHow-how could I have thought it would be possible to be in the presenceâ€ of her fellow nominees including Meryl Streep and Carol Burnett, she asked. â€œI love you all. I revere you all to the bottom of my heart,â€ she said. ColÃ³n-Zayas also thanked the cast and directors of the show. â€œThank you for giving me new life with this show,â€ she said.  And finally she had a message â€œto all Latinas who are looking at me, keep believing and vote, vote for your rights, thank you,â€ While presenting the Emmy for lead actor in a comedy series, famed TV dads Jesse Tyler Ferguson, Damon Wayans and George Lopez took the opportunity to thank their TV wives (and husband). â€œTo be a great TV dad,â€ Lopez said, you have to have a great TV spouse. Wayans thanked his â€œMy Wife and Kidsâ€ co-star Tisha Campbell, Lopez thanked his â€œGeorge Lopezâ€ show TV wife Constance Marie and Ferguson thanked his â€œModern Familyâ€ TV husband Eric Stonestreet. â€œThe Bearâ€ star Jeremy Allen White wins outstanding lead actor in a comedy series at the 76th Emmy Awards. â€œThis show has changed my life,â€ White said while accepting the award for his lead role in Hulu and FXâ€™s beloved culinary series. â€œIt has instilled a faith that change is possible,â€ he continued, adding, â€œif you are able to reach out, you are really truly never actually alone.â€ He also thanked the Television Academy as well as his cast mates and his family. White plays Carmen â€œCarmyâ€ Berzatto, the nervy, ultra-talented chef who returns to his hometown of Chicago following the tragic death of his brother. The chance to take over his familyâ€™s restaurant comes with a return to the Berzattosâ€™ fraught relationships and past traumas. The show is buoyed by a stellar supporting cast as it explores Carmyâ€™s personal and professional life through the brooding performance of White. CNNâ€™s Matt Meyer contributed reporting. Billy Crudup earned the award for outstanding supporting actor in a drama series for his role in â€œThe Morning Showâ€ at the Emmys.  â€œThis is an incredible honor, thank you all,â€ Crudup said. He then gave a shoutout to his wife, actress Naomi Watts, who he noted is an immigrant, and listed her many accolades and successful endeavors.  â€œThis process has been incredible for me and I hope everybody else thatâ€™s involved knows how much it means to me,â€ he said. More on the show: The stakes were raised even higher in the third season of the â€œThe Morning Showâ€ of this taut workplace drama featuring Reese Witherspoon and Jennifer Aniston. The show has already taken home three Primetime Emmys in years past, including one in 2020 for supporting actor Billy Crudup. CNNâ€™s Lisa Respers France and Dan Heching contributed to this report. Ebon Moss-Bachrach wins outstanding supporting actor in a comedy series at the 76th Emmy Awards. While accepting his award, Moss-Bachrach said heâ€™s â€œso gratefulâ€ for â€œThe Bearâ€ and spoke about how much of a â€œprivilegeâ€ it was to work with his cast members, whom he referred to as his â€œincredible family.â€ Moss-Bachrach also thanked his parents, who he joked are â€œtaking such nice care of my catâ€ as well as his children. Hulu and FXâ€™s beloved culinary series is about the inner workings of a high-pressured chef and his staff in a Chicago restaurant. Nominally considered a comedy at tonightâ€™s awards, â€œThe Bearâ€ can be very funny. But itâ€™s best known for its tension-drenched scenes inside the kitchen and its moving exploration of family dynamics. The show has risen from a favorite of TV nerds to the next â€œprestige TVâ€ hit, while the restaurant at the center of the series has transformed from a sandwich shop to a high-end eatery. Father-son duo and Emmys hosts Dan and Eugene Levy kicked off Sundayâ€™s ceremony joking about how hosting is a new experience for the pair, who joked they â€œmore like actors acting like hosts.â€  Dan Levy acknowledged this is the first time they worked together since starring alongside each other in â€œSchittâ€™s Creek,â€ which ended in 2020. Eugene Levy spoke of his famed roles playing movie and TV dads â€” including his role in â€œAmerican Pieâ€ â€” and joked that his best â€œdad roleâ€ was in â€œSchittâ€™s Creekâ€ because it won him his first Emmy. The Canadian-bred actors joked about how they donâ€™t wish to cut any winners off early while they make their acceptance speeches, with Eugene Levy saying, â€œIf youâ€™re going to say anything meaningful or emotional or, god forbid, political, just keep it shortâ€¦â€ Schittâ€™s Creek ran from 2015 to 2020 and starred Catherine Oâ€™Hara, Annie Murphy, Emily Hampshire and Noah Reid, among others. The series won nine Emmys during its run, with five of those wins coming in 2020 for the beloved seriesâ€™ final season. Dan Levy, Eugene Levy, Oâ€™Hara and Murphy all swept the acting categories, and the show won best comedy. Lots of the eveningâ€™s men are eschewing traditional black-tie in favor of something more flamboyant. â€œAbbott Elementaryâ€ star Chris Perfetti impressed in a theatrical ruffled shirt from Christian Sirianoâ€™s Spring 2025 ready-to-wear collection and â€œFalloutâ€ star Aaron Moten arrived in an all-red Kenzo suit with a Nehru collar. â€œThe Traitorsâ€ actor Alan Cumming and fellow Scot Richard Gadd, creator of â€œBaby Reindeer,â€ both wore kilts (in black and traditional tartan, respectively), with the formerâ€™s plaid cummerbund train emerging from his cream Teddy von Ranson jacket to double up as a scarf.Even those men opting for more conventional tailoring incorporated playful touches, from host Dan Levyâ€™s sculpted Loewe neckline to the silky unbuttoned shirt of Jonathan Baileyâ€™s Giorgio Armani suit. See all the best photos the red carpet here. Cast members of â€œThe Bearâ€ have arrived on the red carpet. Hulu and FXâ€™s beloved culinary series, about the inner workings of a high-pressured chef and his staff in a Chicago restaurant, scored 23 nominations in the comedy category this year. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery Meryl Streep arrived on the red carpet stunning in a rosy pink ensemble at the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards. Streep is nominated this year for outstanding supporting actress in a comedy series for her portrayal of Loretta Durkin in â€œOnly Murders in the Building.â€ Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery The cast of Abbott Elementary has arrived on the red carpet. The endearing comedy series about an underfunded Philadelphia public school and the dedicated, passionate teachers and staff who work there is back in the mix at this yearâ€™s Emmy awards with nine nominations, after previously winning four statuettes (including two for creator and star Quinta Brunson) in years past. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery. Matt Bomer and Jonathan Bailey have arrived on the red carpet. Bailey, who plays Tim Laughlin in â€œFellow Travelers,â€ is nominated for outstanding supporting actor in a limited or anthology series. Itâ€™s his first Emmy award nomination. Bomer, who plays Hawkins Fuller in the same series, is also nominated in the category. Adapted by Ron Nyswaner, the central relationship in â€œFellow Travelersâ€ features Bomer and Bailey as two officials working in the orbit of red-baiting Sen. Joe McCarthy (Chris Bauer) and his closeted right-hand man Roy Cohn (Will Brill), who are determined to root out gays to advance their political objectives. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery CNNâ€™s Brian Lowry contributed reporting. Queens from the hit show â€œRuPaulâ€™s Drag Raceâ€ have arrived on the red carpet in an array of colorful looks. The reality competition series, where drag queens battle it out in glamorous challenges for the crown, first aired in 2009 on Logo TV. It has exploded in popularity with more than 15 seasons across three networks, winning 29 Primetime Emmys and spawning a spinoff â€œAll Starsâ€ series, international versions and even a Monopoly game along the way. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery CNNâ€™s Dan Heching contributed reporting. The limited series â€œBaby Reindeerâ€ has topped most-watched lists worldwide since its debut in April, gripping audiences on Netflix while generating headlines and speculation. Series creator and actor Richard Gadd says it is a dramatized version of real events that happened to him, but that it has been altered for artistic and privacy reasons. Heâ€™s also repeatedly urged fans not to seek out the real-life inspirations for the project, which is about a man who is aggressively stalked by a woman he meets in a London bar. But that hasnâ€™t dissuaded super-fans and online sleuths, and now a Scottish woman who says she was defamed by the hit show is seeking a jury trial and damages totaling $170 million for â€œmental anguish, loss of enjoyment of life and loss of business,â€ according to California court filings. The document alleges that the defendants and Gadd told the â€œbiggest lie in television historyâ€ by claiming the story is true. For his part, Gadd previously told UK newspaper The Guardian the story is â€œvery emotionally trueâ€ but that he wanted the series to exist as a piece of art and to protect the identities of those involved. In a June statement to CNN, a spokesperson for Netflix said, â€œWe intend to defend this matter vigorously and to stand by Richard Gaddâ€™s right to tell his story.â€ Selena Gomez has arrived on the red carpet. â€œOnly Murders in the Building,â€ which Gomez acts in and produces, scored 21 primetime Emmy nominations this year, including her first individual acting nomination. The series stars Gomez, Steve Martin and Martin Short as three neighbors in an upscale New York building who are true crime fans. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery Eugene and Dan Levy, co-hosts of the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards, have arrived on the red carpet in style. The father and son duo co-starred in the Emmy-winning sitcom â€œSchittâ€™s Creekâ€ and follow in the footsteps of recent hosts Anthony Anderson, Kenan Thompson and Cedric the Entertainer. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery Liza ColÃ³n-Zayas, whoâ€™s nominated for an award tonight for her performance as Tina Marrero in â€œThe Bear,â€ has arrived on the red carpet glittering in a green gown. Itâ€™s the actressâ€™ first ever Emmy nomination, but one of many that the beloved FX series received this year. â€œThe Bear,â€ set in a Chicago sandwich shop-turned-high-end eatery, scored 23 nominations this year, breaking the comedy record of 22 set by the NBC hit â€œ30 Rockâ€ back in 2009. Check out more of tonightâ€™s best looks in our Emmys red carpet photo gallery Even the most accomplished TV binger doesnâ€™t have enough time to watch all of this yearâ€™s top shows before tonightâ€™s ceremony gets underway in Los Angeles. But if the proceedings at the Peacock Theater pique your curiosity about a series youâ€™ve never tried, hereâ€™s where to watch them: Donâ€™t see your pick? More are listed in our full Emmy shows viewing guide â€œShÅgun,â€ the historical drama based on James Clavellâ€™s bestselling novel, broke a record with its 25 Emmy nominations. The series became only the second non-English language program to be nominated in the outstanding drama category. The hit Netflix series â€œSquid Gameâ€ was the first in 2022. â€œShÅgunâ€ also earned nominations for several of its stars, including Hiroyuki Sanada for outstanding lead actor in a drama series; Anna Sawai for outstanding lead actress; and both Tadanobu Asano and Takehiro Hira competing for outstanding supporting actor. In total, â€œShÅgunâ€ received 25 nominations, the most of any series this year, which helped FX garner 93 nominations â€” a new high for the network. Televisionâ€™s biggest night, the 76th Primetime Emmy Awards, will take place at 8 p.m. ET tonight at the Peacock Theater in downtown Los Angeles. The ceremony will air on ABC and stream the next day on Hulu. Live red carpet coverage begins at 6 p.m. ET on ABC. You can follow along with live updates on this page for all the fashion, award winners and buzzy moments. The father and son duo Eugene and Dan Levy, who co-starred in the Emmy-winning sitcom â€œSchittâ€™s Creek,â€ are tonightâ€™s hosts of the 76th Emmy Awards. The two said in a joint statement last month that they are â€œthrilled to able to raise a glass to this extraordinary season of television.â€ The pair will follow most recent Emmys hosts Anthony Anderson, Kenan Thompson and Cedric the Entertainer. No, youâ€™re not imagining things. It was â€œtelevisionâ€™s biggest nightâ€ a matter of months ago. Due to a pair of Hollywood strikes, the 75th Emmy Awards were postponed until last January. When the delayed awards show finally took place, we saw â€œThe Bearâ€ and â€œSuccessionâ€ as the biggest winners, picking up six Emmys each. The industryâ€™s writers and actors remain back at work and we return to our regularly scheduled programming: Tonightâ€™s awards will celebrate shows released between June 1, 2023 and May 31, 2024. â€œSuccessionâ€ has concluded, having used its strong showing at the January awards to cement its status as one of the best drama series in recent years. But â€œThe Bearâ€ looks poised to have another big night on the back of its critically lauded second season. The FX hitâ€™s third season was released in June and will be eligible to contend during next yearâ€™s Emmys.  The nominees for the 76th Emmy Awards â€” televisionâ€™s top honor â€” were announced earlier this summer, and â€œThe Bearâ€ ate it up. The beloved FX series, set in a Chicago sandwich shop-turned-high-end eatery, scored 23 nominations this year, breaking the record of 22 set by the NBC hit â€œ30 Rockâ€ back in 2009. In the drama category, â€œShÅgunâ€ had the most nominations this year with 25. The all-time record of 32 nominations, held by HBOâ€™s â€œGame of Thronesâ€ since 2016, remains unbroken. HBO is owned by CNNâ€™s parent company. Some past favorites, including â€œSuccessionâ€ and â€œTed Lasso,â€ were not in contention this year, but â€œThe Crown,â€ â€œThe Morning Showâ€ and â€œOnly Murders in the Buildingâ€ became the new â€œlegacy showsâ€ with multiple nominations. Here are some of the nominees to watch tonight: Outstanding drama series: Outstanding comedy series: Outstanding limited series: Outstanding reality/competition series: Outstanding talk series: Outstanding lead actor in a comedy series: Outstanding lead actress in a drama series: See the full list of nominees here.

Title: The one Harris comment Trump and his allies have spent $38 million for voters to see | CNN Politics
Content: On an August afternoon last year in Washington, Kamala Harris appeared at a retail village to promote the Biden administrationâ€™s economic record. â€œBidenomics is working,â€ the vice president announced, touting the latest round of job numbers. â€œThat is called Bidenomics, and we are very proud of Bidenomics.â€ It was a fateful declaration, one that has dogged Harris since she took over as the Democratic standard-bearer and has attempted to seize the mantle of change candidate in the 2024 presidential race. The Trump campaign and its allies have spent more than $38 million replaying that soundbite almost 70,000 times in campaign advertisements since Harris became the Democratic nominee, looking to capitalize on persistent voter concerns about the economy and blunt Harrisâ€™ turn-the-page messaging by yoking her to President Joe Bidenâ€™s record. One of the ads, backed by more than $13 million, simply juxtaposes Harris on the campaign trail in 2024, speaking to voter concerns about rising prices, with the clip from 2023, and includes no other narration. â€œEveryday prices are too high â€“ food, rent, gas, back-to-school clothes,â€ Harris says in the clip featured in the ad. What Immediately follows is the 2023 clip of her saying, â€œThat is called Bidenomics.â€ Another one of the ads, also backed by more than $13 million, contrasts news coverage of inflation with the same 2023 clip, taking the same spare approach, also with no other narration. A third ad from the Trump campaign, launched last week and already backed by more than $3 million, opens with the clip of Harris saying that â€œBidenomics is working,â€ before a narrator cuts in with â€œItâ€™s notâ€ and references more critical news coverage of inflation. â€œYet Harris still says, â€˜Bidenomics working.â€™ No, it isnâ€™t,â€ the ad ends. A fourth ad featuring the soundbite went up Friday. Throughout the campaign, Trump and his allies have taken a two-track approach to their attacks against Harris â€“ on the one hand linking immigration and crime, and amplifying public safety concerns; while on the other, slamming the Biden-Harris economic record, with a particular focus on inflation. The spree of ads replaying Harrisâ€™ endorsement of â€œBidenomicsâ€ reflects the latter approach, and that share of the pro-Trump messaging has been increasing in recent weeks as the campaign fine-tunes its advertising strategy for the final weeks of the race. The ads are aimed at leveraging the advantage that polls show voters give Trump on economic issues and magnifying persistent concerns about inflation and a potential recession â€“ even as inflation in the actual economy has slowed and job growth has continued. Harris and her allies, meanwhile, have made a concerted effort to blunt those criticisms, also leaning into economic messaging in their campaign advertising. Last week, Harrisâ€™ campaign launched a series of ads on her economic pitch, specifically tailored to key swing states. â€œLowering the cost of living will be a defining goal of my presidency. Iâ€™ll lower the cost of insulin and prescription drugs for everyone. And I will work to pass the first ever federal ban on price gouging on food. More than 100 million Americans will get a tax cut. We will end Americaâ€™s housing shortage by building 3 million new homes and rentals that are affordable for the middle class,â€ Harris says in the ads. In addition, her campaign has spent more than $10 million airing an ad in which Harris says, â€œYou want lower prices and lower taxes. I believe you want to just not get by, but you want to get ahead,â€ before delivering her pitch for an â€œopportunity economy.â€ And another top Harris ad contrasts her approach with Trumpâ€™s. â€œItâ€™s a very different vision than Donald Trumpâ€™s. His plans will raise costs and taxes on the vast majority of Americans. We need to be thinking about the future and how we make it better for families like yours,â€ Harris says in the ad. Democrats â€“ including Biden and Harris â€“ ditched the â€œBidenomicsâ€ branding long ago as part of their messaging on the economy. For the vice president, her approach to the issue since ascending to the top of the Democratic ticket speaks to the balancing act she has faced when it comes to embracing the administrationâ€™s record, including during her first sit-down interview as the nominee last month with CNN. â€œSo you maintain Bidenomics is a success?â€ CNNâ€™s Dana Bash asked Harris during an exchange about her economic plans. â€œI maintain that when we do the work,â€ Harris responded before launching into a litany of the administrationâ€™s achievements. â€œIâ€™ll say that thatâ€™s good work. Thereâ€™s more to do, but thatâ€™s good work.â€ The backdrop to the back-and-forth over who is best for votersâ€™ pocketbooks is a US economy that has continued to post solid data, even as prices are higher than four years ago and interest rates are elevated. Inflation has slowed significantly from its peak in 2022, and the US economy added 142,000 jobs in August, marking stronger growth than a worrisome lower number in July. Still, the ads from the Trump campaign also reflect the basic conundrum facing all politicians â€“ they spend hours before the public, staking out positions and making statements, all while political operatives and ad-makers watch for a moment to capitalize. Harris, standing in southeast DC in August 2023, could not have known that exactly one year later, she would face the challenge of pitching an entirely different vision to voters.

Title: Manchin signals he could endorse Harris while Romney stays coy | CNN Politics
Content: Sen. Joe Manchin, the conservative Democrat-turned-independent who had toyed with a presidential run and has long been a thorn in the side of the left, has been mum about the candidate heâ€™s backing in November. But that could soon change. In an interview with CNN, the veteran West Virginia senator signaled he may get off the sidelines. And he plans to speak to Vice President Kamala Harris soon. â€œOh I could see that, yes,â€ Manchin told CNN when asked if heâ€™d endorse a candidate before November. Utah Sen. Mitt Romney, the Republican Partyâ€™s 2012 presidential nominee who voted twice to convict former President Donald Trump in his impeachment trials, reiterated his disdain for Trump â€“ and objected to the former presidentâ€™s refusal to say at last weekâ€™s debate that he wanted Ukraine to win its war against Russia. Asked twice if he would endorse Harris, Romney pointedly refused to say. â€œIâ€™m certainly not going to be voting for former President Trump, and I think thatâ€™s been very clear,â€ Romney said when asked the first time whether heâ€™d back Harris. Asked again about supporting Harris, Romney said: â€œI donâ€™t have anything on that at this stage.â€ The comments by Manchin and Romney â€“ two retiring senators who have been on the outs with their respective partyâ€™s base â€“ underscore how Trump has turned off some more moderate voters but also how Harris herself has yet to close the deal with right-leaning voters skeptical of the former president. A third Trump detractor, GOP Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, doesnâ€™t plan to vote for Harris, even as she said of the former presidentâ€™s debate performance, â€œI donâ€™t think it was Donald Trumpâ€™s best evening.â€ Manchin, who refused to say in 2012 if heâ€™d vote for Barack Obama for reelection, seems most likely of the three to endorse Harris. The former Democrat downplayed Harrisâ€™ more liberal politics and sounded positive about the direction of her campaign. And he rebutted criticism that she was too far to the left for him. â€œI think sheâ€™s moving in the right direction. Things Iâ€™m hearing are sounding very good,â€ Manchin said, adding that he wants to make sure the two have â€œa very good conversation. We will do that.â€ â€œShe comes from California. I expect her to be different than where I came from,â€ Manchin added. â€œShe seems to be looking at the larger picture now, which is very encouraging.â€ Manchin said heâ€™s been playing phone tag with Harris and is â€œlooking forward to a conversationâ€ about energy, the national debt and keeping in tact the Senateâ€™s filibuster, the potent stall tactic that requires 60 votes to overcome. â€œI would like to make sure that she understands the need for us to have a filibuster in the Senate, being a former senator, of how it kind of calms things down, makes us work together,â€ he said. â€œIf theyâ€™re willing to discard all of that, theyâ€™re willing to throw caution to the wind, weâ€™re in serious problems.â€ In the interview in the Capitol last week, Romney heavily criticized the former presidentâ€™s refusal to say that Ukraine should win the war against Russia and his use of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban as a character witness of sorts. â€œThe president surely had to say, â€˜Of course, I want Ukraine to win. I want Ukraine to be successful,â€™ and then he can talk about how you define success and winning. But we stand with democracies. We stand with nations that are now being invaded by their neighbors, particularly invaded by Russia,â€ Romney added. â€œSo, it was a huge gap that I think caused a collective gasp from nations around the world.â€ Romney contended that Orbanâ€™s â€œauthoritarian tendenciesâ€ are well known, â€œand thatâ€™s not someone who I would say, â€˜This is a badge of honor, you know, heâ€™s the guy who likes me.â€™â€

Title: Live updates: FBI investigating apparent assassination attempt of Trump in Florida | CNN Politics
Content: Our live coverage of the apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump has moved here. Ryan Routh had repeatedly called for bolstering Taiwanâ€™s defenses against China and hoped to set up a foreign legion akin to that in Ukraine.  The man, who was detained in connection with an apparent attempt to assassinate former president Donald Trump on Sunday, is listed as an â€œInternational Volunteer Center Coordinatorâ€ on a website named Taiwan Foreign Legion.  The group claims it is â€œrecruiting former military and civilians from around the worldâ€ willing to defend Taiwan in the event of a war with China.  CNN reached out to over a dozen people listed as â€œsupportersâ€ on the groupâ€™s website. But several said they had not heard of the group or its activities, and some had never heard of Routh.   All claimed they did not know how their names and contact information had been shared on the pro-Taiwan website.  Unlike Ukraine, Taiwan does not have an official foreign legion. Taiwanâ€™s Foreign Ministry and Defense Ministry declined to comment on Routh.  Chinaâ€™s ruling Communist Party says Taiwan is part of its territory, despite never having controlled it, and has vowed to take the island by force if necessary. The US is bound by law to supply the self-governing island with weapons to defend itself, and support for Taiwan is a rare issue of broadly bipartisan consensus in Washington.  Ryan Wesley Routh decried Donald Trump as an â€œidiot,â€ a â€œbuffoonâ€ and a â€œfoolâ€ in his self-published book on the war in Ukraine and geopolitics. The 58-year-old, who was detained Sunday in connection with an apparent assassination attempt on Trump, wrote last year about his unsuccessful efforts to aid Ukraine in its war against Russia and also weighed in on multiple global crises. Routh wrote that the former US presidentâ€™s withdrawal from the Iran nuclear deal in 2018 was a â€œtremendous blunderâ€ that drove Tehran closer to Moscow, which it has supplied with drones that have caused devastation across Ukraine. Routh also gave his opinions on the political situation in Afghanistan, and urged Afghan refugees to fight for Ukraine. He also wrote about Taiwan, North Korea and Venezuela, drawing comparisons between the authoritarian rule of President Nicolas Maduro and the January 6 insurrection at the US Capitol. Appearing to reference his former support for Trump, Routh wrote that he must take part of the blame for electing him as president, writing: â€œbut I am man enough to say that I misjudged and made a terrible mistake.â€ Leaders around the world are condemning the apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump and offering their support. Hereâ€™s what theyâ€™re saying: The FBI said it â€œis investigating what appears to be an attempted assassinationâ€ of Donald Trump at his Florida golf club, just two months after an attempt to kill the Republican presidential nominee at a Pennsylvania rally. The former president was not harmed. Ryan Wesley Routh, a 58-year-old owner of a small construction company in Hawaii, has been detained in connection with Sundayâ€™s incident, according to three law enforcement sources. Hereâ€™s what happened: Ryan Wesley Routh, who authorities suspect was planning to attack former President Donald Trump as he played a round of golf, was a staunch supporter of Ukraine and visited the country in 2022. Routh traveled to Ukraine following Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of its neighbor more than two years ago, according to video and images geolocated by CNN to Kyivâ€™s Independence Square, as well as interviews with foreign press. Video shows Routh attended a rally at the square in support of Ukrainian troops on May 1, 2022, and visited the same location about six weeks later, where a photo shows him standing beside a Ukraine flag emblazoned with an appeal for international volunteers to support the war effort In an April 2022 video by AFP in Kyiv, Routh called Putin a â€œterroristâ€ and said â€œhe needs to be ended.â€ A representative from Ukraineâ€™s foreign legion told CNN that Routh had contacted them several times but that he was never part of the military unit in which overseas volunteers fight. Routh also expressed support for Ukraine on social media. In dozens of posts on X in 2022, he said he was willing to die in the fight and that â€œwe need to burn the Kremlin to the ground.â€  Routh then used Facebook to encourage foreigners to fight in the war. He tried to enlist Afghan conscripts in a flurry of posts, beginning in October 2023, presenting himself as an off-the-books liaison for the Ukrainian government.   This post has been updated with more information on Routhâ€™s time in Ukraine. A representative from Ukraineâ€™s foreign legion confirmed with CNN that Ryan Wesley Routh had contacted them several times but said he was never part of the military unit in which overseas volunteers fight. Shaguri said â€œthe best way to describe his messages is â€” delusional ideas.â€ Routh expressed support for Ukraine in dozens of X posts in 2022, saying he was willing to die in the fight and that â€œwe need to burn the Kremlin to the ground.â€ He also visited Ukraine in 2022, according to video and photos geolocated by CNN as well as media interviews he gave while there.  Routh then used his Facebook account last year to encourage foreigners to fight in the war. He tried to enlist Afghan conscripts in a flurry of posts, beginning in October 2023, presenting himself as an off-the-books liaison for the Ukrainian government. Newsweek Romania journalist Remus Cernea, who met the man detained in connection with an apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump in Ukraine on several occasions, told CNN he was surprised by Ryan Routhâ€™s involvement in the incident. Cernea first met Routh in Kyivâ€™s Independence Square in June of 2022, where Routh was rallying people to join the foreign legion or to help Ukraine through various humanitarian aid organizations. At the time, Routh gave Newsweek Romania an interview where he said: When Cernea met Routh again about a year later, he said, Routh was visibly frustrated that more people had not come to Ukraineâ€™s help. â€œWhy arenâ€™t there thousands of people here in Kyiv coming to support and join the foreign legion, why arenâ€™t they here?â€ Cernea remembers him lamenting. Ryan Wesley Routh, a 58-year-old owner of a small construction company, has been detained in connection with an apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump in Florida, according to three law enforcement sources. Hereâ€™s what we know about him: This post has been updated with the latest developments. Ryan Wesley Routh, the 58-year-old man detained Sunday in connection with an apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump in Florida, self-published a book last year detailing his efforts to support Ukraine in the war against Russia. In the 291-page book, Routh described his disillusionment with the war in Ukraine, which he called â€œunwinnable.â€ The book also discussed the Taliban takeover of Afghanistan and the political situation in Taiwan, which has faced growing military threats from China. The book, released on Amazon with no publisher listed, is titled: â€œUkraineâ€™s Unwinnable War: The Fatal Flaw of Democracy, World Abandonment and the Global Citizen-Taiwan, Afghanistan, North Korea and the end of Humanity.â€ CNN has not independently verified his accounts in the book. In it, Routh describes how he had traveled to the Poland-Ukraine border in an effort to enlist in the war â€” but â€œat 56 with absolutely no military experience I was reluctantly turned away by the staffâ€ at the border office. Instead, he tried to enlist more fighters for the war effort â€” traveling to Kyiv and setting up a makeshift volunteer center at Independence Square before it was disassembled by police. He then â€œlost all arguments and calls to city hall,â€ he writes, and spent several months camped out in protest at various locations around the city. â€œI had given every ounce of motivation and energy that I could muster for Ukraine and came up empty handed,â€ he said, describing his unsuccessful attempts to build drones for the Ukrainian army with a team of international engineers.  Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he was shocked after hearing about the apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump. â€œSara and I were shocked by the second assassination attempt against President Trump and were relieved to hear that it too failed. But we should not rely on luck,â€ he wrote on X. Federal agents investigating an apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump on Sunday expect a federal court in South Florida will require â€œa mental health assessmentâ€ of Ryan Wesley Routh before any possible criminal proceedings, a law enforcement source told CNN.  Based on numerous â€œunusual rantsâ€ believed to be posted by Routh online regarding international geopolitical events, the source said federal investigators expect his mental health will be examined as part of court proceedings to determine whether he is fit for any trial.  No charges have been filed, but mental health assessments are not uncommon in cases involving threats to federal officials by individuals who may be experiencing mental health issues, the source said. CNN is attempting to determine if Routh has attorney representation. Kennedy likely misspoke about the name of the investigating agency, as the National Marine Fisheries Services is an organization that falls under the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. CNN has reached out to the agencies for comment. On Saturday, Kennedy claimed he wrote a letter in response, accusing the investigators of killing whales and marine wildlife with â€œgiant offshore wind farms off the East Coast.â€ A story resurfaced last month that Kennedy once used a chainsaw to cut off the head of a dead whale carcass that washed onshore of his Cape Cod family home and then drove the whale head back to New York. The story was recounted by Kennedyâ€™s daughter Kathleen â€œKickâ€ Kennedy in a 2012 interview with Town & Country Magazine. An environmental group, the Center for Biological Diversity Action Fund, had called for Kennedy to be investigated over the incident, arguing in a letter to NOAA that his actions could have jeopardized scientific research . Pennsylvania Gov. Josh Shapiro on Sunday condemned Republican vice presidential nominee and Ohio Sen. JD Vance for refusing to walk back his baseless claims that migrants are eating pets in Springfield, Ohio.   Shapiroâ€™s comments came after Vance defended false claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets earlier Sunday in an interview with CNNâ€™s Dana Bash. Officials at the city and state level have repeatedly tried to end the rumor. Springfield officials have told press and city commission meetings that there are no credible reports of animal abuse by immigrants in the area. Shapiro also told CNN that he anticipates a close race between Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris in Pennsylvania but noted that heâ€™s optimistic his state will show up for Harris.  â€œI think what Iâ€™m seeing more and more of is not just the folks who are lining up to vote for her, but those who are enthusiastic about her candidacy in communities that oftentimes are not enthusiastic about Democratic candidates â€” and encouraging their neighbors to be for them as well,â€ Shapiro said. â€œSo Iâ€™m really hopeful.â€  Former President Donald Trump on Sunday continued raising doubts about election integrity and claimed, without evidence, that it was â€œnot possibleâ€ for the US Postal Service to properly â€œrun the 2024 Presidential Election.â€ â€œThe United States Postal Service has admitted that it is a poorly run mess that is experiencing mail loss and delays at a level never seen before. With this being the FACT, how can we possibly be expected to allow or trust the U.S. Postal Service to run the 2024 Presidential Election? It is not possible for them to do so. HELP!â€ Trump posted on Truth Social.  While election officials have warned that the US Postal Service may delay mail-in voting, citing systemic issues in the postal service as more Americans prepare to cast their ballots by mail, there is no evidence that its â€œnot possibleâ€ for the postal service to handle mail-in ballots. Republican Ohio Gov. Mike DeWine on Sunday flatly denied the false rumor spread by Donald Trump that Haitian immigrants are eating pets in Ohio and praised immigrants for their positive influence on the community. â€œNo. Absolutely not,â€ DeWine said when asked if heâ€™d seen any evidence of the pet-eating rumor, a tale many Republicans, including Trump and his running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, have promoted. â€œLet me tell you what we do know, though. What we know is that the Haitians who are in Springfield are legal,â€ the governor said on ABCâ€™s â€œThis Week.â€ â€œThey came to Springfield to work.â€ DeWine acknowledged the city was having some issues adjusting to the influx of mostly Haitian immigrants through a federal immigration program, but he said they were working to deal with the issues. â€œWhen you go from a population of 58,000 and add 15,000 people onto that, youâ€™re going to have some challenges and some problems,â€ the governor said. â€œAnd weâ€™re addressing those. Weâ€™re working on those every single day.â€ But the governor said the Haitian immigrants in Springfield are â€œpositive influencesâ€ on the community and â€œany comment about that otherwise, I think is hurtful and is not helpful to the city of Springfield and the people of Springfield.â€ Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance on Sunday said he learned his lesson about speaking for Donald Trump after previously stating the former president would veto a national abortion ban.  â€œI think that Iâ€™ve learned my lesson on speaking for the president before he and I have actually talked about an issue. What he has said at the debate, which is quite explicit, is he doesnâ€™t support a national ban. He thinks itâ€™s ridiculous to talk about vetoing a piece of legislation that isnâ€™t going to come before the president in the first place,â€ Vance said on NBCâ€™s â€œMeet the Press.â€ On the debate stage, Trump said that he doesnâ€™t support a national abortion ban, but wouldnâ€™t explicitly say he would veto one, rather that it wouldnâ€™t make it through Congress. â€œWe hadnâ€™t discussed it,â€ Vance said. â€œWe still havenâ€™t discussed it, by the way, because itâ€™s not realistic.â€ Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance on Sunday sought to distance the Trump campaign from far-right agitator Laura Loomer, stating that while he doesnâ€™t agree with her comments about Vice President Kamala Harris, it is not â€œan issue of national importâ€ or insulting to talk about â€œdietary preferences.â€  Two days before the ABC presidential debate, Loomer said if Harris, whose mother was from India, wins the 2024 election, â€œthe White House will smell like curry & White House speeches will be facilitated via a call center.â€ Pressed on whether he disavows those comments, especially considering his wife is the daughter of Indian immigrants, Vance said, â€œI just told you I donâ€™t like those comments, and I think that we ought to focus on Kamala Harrisâ€™ policy failures.â€ When Trump landed in Philadelphia on Tuesday before his debate against Vice Kamala Harris, Loomer was among the close allies seen deboarding his private plane. He said Friday that he doesnâ€™t control Loomer, whom he described as a â€œfree spiritâ€ and â€œsupporter.â€ Former President Donald Trump on Sunday said he hates Taylor Swift, days after the pop megastar endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris. â€œI HATE TAYLOR SWIFT!â€ Trump posted on his Truth Social platform Swift endorsed Harris after the ABC presidential debate on Tuesday, ending speculation about whether she would share her political views ahead of Novemberâ€™s election. â€œRecently I was made aware that AI of â€˜meâ€™ falsely endorsing Donald Trumpâ€™s presidential run was posted to his site. It really conjured up my fears around AI, and the dangers of spreading misinformation,â€ Swift posted on Instagram. â€œIt brought me to the conclusion that I need to be very transparent about my actual plans for this election as a voter,â€ Swift continued. â€œThe simplest way to combat misinformation is with the truth. I will be casting my vote for Kamala Harris and Tim Walz in the 2024 Presidential Election.â€ Asked about the endorsement on Fox News Wednesday morning, Trump cast Swift as a â€œvery liberal personâ€ and said she will â€œprobably pay a price for it in the marketplace.â€ Former President Donald Trump has conjured up an inflammatory false claim about Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ policy positions â€” baselessly saying Friday that Harris is talking about forcing Americans to serve in the military. Trump claimed at a rally in Las Vegas that voting for Harris means voting for war with Russia and voting to bring back the draft, a system in which some men are conscripted into involuntary service in the armed forces. Trump continued: â€œWould anybody like to be drafted, in the audience? Because thatâ€™s what theyâ€™re doing. Sheâ€™s already talking about bringing back the draft. She wants to bring back the draft, and draft your child, and put them in a war that should never have happened.â€ Facts First: Trumpâ€™s claim is false. Harris is not talking about bringing back the draft and has not put forward any proposals to bring back the draft. Trumpâ€™s campaign did not respond Saturday to CNNâ€™s requests for any evidence for his claim. A Harris campaign aide said, â€œWe have no idea what heâ€™s talking about.â€ The US has not had a draft since 1973, the year it completed its military withdrawal from Vietnam. (Trump received five draft deferments during the Vietnam War draft, four because he was a college student and a fifth on account of a doctorâ€™s diagnosis of bone spurs in his heels.) Since 1973, the country has used an all-volunteer force. Regardless of the wishes of any president, launching a new draft would require Congress to pass legislation. Republican vice presidential candidate JD Vance on Sunday defended false claims about Haitian immigrants eating the pets of residents in Springfield, Ohio in an interview with CNNâ€™s Dana Bash on â€œState of the Union.â€ Asked to support his claims, Vance pointed to what he said are firsthand accounts from constituents who have told him this is happening, though he didnâ€™t provide the evidence.  Bash replied, â€œYou just said that this is a story that you created.â€ Vance said, â€œIt comes from firsthand accounts from my constituents. I say that weâ€™re creating a story, meaning weâ€™re creating the American media focusing on it. I didnâ€™t create 20,000 illegal migrants coming into Springfield thanks to Kamala Harrisâ€™ policies. Her policies did that. But yes, we created the actual focus that allowed the American media to talk about this story and the suffering caused by Kamala Harrisâ€™ policies.â€ The city of Springfield notes on its website that approximately 12,000 to 15,000 immigrants live in Clark County, and that Haitian immigrants are there legally as part of a parole program that allows citizens and lawful residents to apply to have their family members from Haiti come to the United States. Local officials at the city and state level have repeatedly tried to end the rumor about immigrants eating pets. Springfield officials have told press and city commission meetings that there are no credible reports of animal abuse by immigrants in the area. On Tuesday, Vance said itâ€™s possible the false claim might not be true, but he encouraged his followers to continue posting â€œcat memes.â€ As CNN reported, Springfield Mayor Rob Rue said Thursday that the claims are â€œhurting our citizens and hurting our community,â€ adding itâ€™s â€œfrustratingâ€ that some of the rhetoric is coming from Vance.  US Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg on Sunday swiped at former President Donald Trump over the baseless claims heâ€™s pushed that immigrants in Springfield, Ohio are eating pets. Local officials at the city and state level have repeatedly tried to end the rumor. Springfield officials have told press and city commission meetings that there are no credible reports of animal abuse by immigrants in the area. Buttigieg continued, â€œThey go for something that is so outrageous that you actually canâ€™t ignore it. The media canâ€™t ignore whatâ€™s going on, because very real pain has been inflicted on and fear, by the way, on people in this community and other communities around the country.â€ Sen. Joe Manchin, the conservative Democrat-turned-independent who had toyed with a presidential run and has long been a thorn in the side of the left, has been mum about the candidate heâ€™s backing in November. But that could soon change, as Manchin signaled he may get off the sidelines and plans to speak to Vice President Kamala Harris soon. Sen. Mitt Romney, the Republican Partyâ€™s 2012 presidential nominee who voted twice to convict former President Donald Trump in his impeachment trials, reiterated his disdain for Trump â€“ and objected to the former presidentâ€™s refusal to say at last weekâ€™s debate that he wanted Ukraine to win its war against Russia. Asked twice if he could endorse Harris, Romney pointedly refused to say. The comments by Manchin and Romney â€“ two retiring senators who have been on the outs with their respective partyâ€™s base â€“ underscore how Trump has turned off some more moderate voters but also how Harris herself has yet to close the deal with right-leaning voters turned off by the former president. A third Trump detractor, GOP Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska, doesnâ€™t plan to vote for Harris, even as she said of the former presidentâ€™s debate performance, â€œI donâ€™t think it was Donald Trumpâ€™s best evening.â€ Read more here. Wittenberg University in Springfield, Ohio, is taking â€œextreme precautionsâ€ in response to an email that threatened an on-campus shooting targeting Haitians on Sunday, according to university officials. The threat comes as several prominent Republicans, including former President Donald Trump and his running mate, Sen. JD Vance, have promoted false claims that Haitian migrants in Ohio are killing and eating family pets. Local officials at the city and state level have repeatedly tried to end the rumor. Springfield officials have told press and city commission meetings that there are no credible reports of animal abuse by immigrants in the area. The threat to Wittenberg University â€œtargeted Haitian members of our community,â€ a statement released Saturday said. â€œWittenberg Police are cooperating with the Springfield Police Division and the FBI to investigate this threat.â€   All activities have been canceled on Sunday, and the Springfield Police Division will increase patrols on campus, the universityâ€™s statement said, adding that those who are on or near campus should â€œprepare for additional instructions or a lockdown if we learn more from the ongoing investigation.â€ Wittenberg University had 1,288 undergraduate students enrolled in the fall 2023 term, according to its website. CNN has reached out to the Wittenberg Police Department for additional information.  Donald Trump wanted to spend this week attacking one of Democratic rival Kamala Harrisâ€™ biggest political vulnerabilities. Instead, he spent most of the week falsely claiming that migrants are eating pets in a small town in Ohio and defending his embrace of a far-right agitator whose presence is causing concern among his allies. Trumpâ€™s repeated parroting of unfounded social media rumors about Haitian migrants in Ohio eating pets stole headlines during a trip West, including stops in Arizona and Nevada, late this week. The promotion of the claims overshadowed a series of speeches aimed at the economy and blaming Harris for border security failures. Trump, in a news conference in California on Friday, promised â€œlarge deportationsâ€ from Springfield, Ohio â€” the town that has become a political flashpoint as Republicans, including Trump and his running mate, Ohio Sen. JD Vance, spread false claims about Haitian immigrants eating pets. The city of Springfield notes on its website that approximately 12,000 to 15,000 immigrants live in Clark County, and that Haitian immigrants are there legally as part of a parole program that allows citizens and lawful residents to apply to have their family members from Haiti come to the United States. Read more here. New polling post-debate from ABC News and Ipsos finds Vice President Kamala Harris leading former President Donald Trump among likely voters, with the margin in the race unchanged from ABC News polling conducted in late August.  Overall, 52% of likely voters back Harris, 46% Trump in the poll, the same margin the pollsters found among likely voters in an August 23 through 27 poll. Among adults, the survey suggests little change in the dynamic between the candidates on the campaignâ€™s central issues. Trump continues to be more widely trusted to handle the economy (46% Trump to 39% Harris) and immigration (47% Trump to 37% Harris), while Harris is broadly more trusted on abortion (48% Harris to 34% Trump) and protecting American democracy (45% Harris to 38% Trump). The ABC News poll was conducted online Sept. 11-13 among a random national sample of 3,276 adults and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 2 points. For results among the 2,196 likely voters, the error margin is plus or minus 2 points. Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ campaign and Nebraska Democratic officials are keeping a close eye on any last-minute efforts to change the election law that awards the stateâ€™s electoral votes by congressional district, rather than statewide winner. Nebraskaâ€™s unique law presents an opportunity for Democrats to secure one of the stateâ€™s votes by winning the district surrounding Omaha â€” a critical blue dot in a sea of red. The stateâ€™s Republican Gov. Jim Pillen made it clear Friday that he is willing to call a special legislative session on changing the state to a â€œwinner takes allâ€ model before the November election â€” but said in a statement that he doesnâ€™t yet have â€œconcrete and public indicationâ€ that enough lawmakers would back the move. Nebraska Democratic chairwoman Jane Kleeb said Saturday that Pillenâ€™s statement signals Republicans â€œdo not have the votes to change the fair electoral system we have in Nebraska.â€ When the matter of changing the law came up for a vote in the state legislature earlier this year, it was 17 votes shy of passing. Kleeb said Saturday that those 17 votes remain â€œvery solid.â€ Bottom line: If Vice President Kamala Harris can win the â€œblue wallâ€ states of Wisconsin, Michigan and Pennsylvania, plus the blue dot vote in Nebraska, she can likely reach 270 electoral votes without winning a single other contested battleground state. That means a potential change to the law â€” which would be a shocking development so close to the election â€” could have serious implications for each presidential campaign. Democratic vice presidential nominee Tim Walz made a direct pitch to Muslim and Arab American voters in Michigan, addressing those concerned about the Biden administrationâ€™s handling of the war in Gaza. The Minnesota governor used an interview Friday to reiterate Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ support for a ceasefire-hostage deal between Israel and Hamas, and argued Trumpâ€™s record of targeting Muslim Americans is â€œnot in your best interest.â€ Harris is more cognizant of the suffering of Palestinians than Trump, Walz said in the interview with WXMI in Grand Rapids, Michigan, addressing those from the â€œAbandon Harrisâ€ movement. Illustrating the constant balancing act for the Democratic ticket on the Middle East, Walz also emphasized the importance of Israelâ€™s self-defense. â€œThatâ€™s why sheâ€™s the person to move us toward a two-state solution, where Israel can be protected, we get our hostages back, and Gaza can be self-determined,â€ he added. Walz contrasted Harrisâ€™ view with Trumpâ€™s previous support of a travel ban that targeted people from Muslim-majority countries, and his calls to send some Muslim members of Congress to their countries of origin. â€œDonald Trump is offering you nothing,â€ Walz said, to voters skeptical of Harris over the issue. â€œThat is not in your best interest.â€

Title: House GOP split on how to address IVF messaging as some push Speaker Johnson to hold a vote before the election | CNN Politics
Content: Multiple House Republicans have been working behind the scenes to convince Speaker Mike Johnson to hold a vote on legislation supporting in vitro fertilization before the November elections but told CNN their efforts have so far been brushed off or even denied. The direct pressure campaign from lawmakers across the GOP conference has ramped up in recent weeks as those Republicans running in competitive races want to showcase their support of IVF, which Democrats have called into question after the Alabama Supreme Court ruling earlier this year that frozen embryos are human beings and those who destroy them can be held liable for wrongful death. The resistance from Johnson to take up legislation on the issue up until this point, according to conversations with some of the lawmakers involved, stems from concerns that Republicans could fail to pass it in their narrowly held Republican majority, and the fear of putting members in a worse spot politically. There is also an acknowledgement that Johnson is trying to balance the needs of his vulnerable members who support the fertility treatments with small-government deficit hawks who resist mandates and conservatives who are against IVF for religious reasons. One GOP lawmaker characterized Johnson as â€œplacatingâ€ the situation by being intentionally vague about whether he would commit to bringing up IVF legislation. â€œYouâ€™re dealing with some people who have older views and tougher districts, and you know, theyâ€™re not going to move,â€ the lawmaker said of Johnson and his House GOP leadership team. Another GOP lawmaker said Johnson simply said no when asked for legislation supporting IVF to be brought up, telling CNN, â€œHeâ€™s been more direct with me.â€ â€œMultiple members have had conversations with leadership about IVF,â€ the lawmaker added. â€œMultiple members have filed bills about IVF. Itâ€™s something, particularly if youâ€™re in a purple district or a swing district, that would be really helpful, but they havenâ€™t done anything on it yet. I donâ€™t know why.â€ While a third GOP lawmaker, who has also made the case to Johnson about the need for House Republicans to take a public stance on IVF, said the hesitancy among his partyâ€™s leadership is starting to thaw. â€œMy conference is hesitant to move on bills of this nature, but I think they understand more and more that there is a need to,â€ the lawmaker said. With the House only scheduled to be in session for a few weeks before the presidential election, Johnsonâ€™s top priority has been to keep the government open past the September 30 deadline, which has already hit serious roadblocks. But when asked about his conversations with members and if he supports bringing forward IVF legislation before the election, Johnson told CNN, â€œI think weâ€™ve been very consistent. Our party is in support of IVF in every way, shape or form. If thereâ€™s a legislative opportunity to vote on it, Iâ€™m sure we would. Iâ€™ll have to see. Iâ€™ve been busy on a lot of other things but will check into that.â€ Six months earlier, Johnson said he did not believe Congress had a role to play, dismissing the need for IVF legislation. Republicans have been on the defensive with their reproductive health care messaging since the overturning of Roe v. Wade more than two years ago, and many have tried to develop a pro-IVF message in the wake of the Alabama Supreme Court ruling to win back moderate women. Former President Donald Trump called himself a â€œleader on IVF, which is fertilizationâ€ during the presidential debate this week and has introduced a policy that would pay for treatments. House GOP Conference Chairwoman Elise Stefanik told CNN following the debate, â€œPresident Trump has been very clear, Iâ€™ve been very clear. We support IVF. We are pro-babies, pro-families.â€ But Republicans have so far failed to channel their support into a legislative response. Senate Republicans voted down a bill in June that would have guaranteed access to IVF nationwide, arguing that the legislation was unnecessary, and Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer is bringing the bill up for a vote again ahead of the election to keep the pressure on Senate Republicans. And while House Republicans project that there is universal support for IVF within their conference, some were less than enthusiastic about voting on legislation in support of the treatments, particularly in the lead up to the election. â€œIâ€™m disinterested in this topic,â€ GOP Rep. Thomas Massie of Kentucky told CNN. GOP Rep. Chip Roy of Texas stated that Republicans should keep a narrow focus on government funding, inflation and the US-Mexico border â€œand then get the frigginâ€™ hell out of here.â€ And GOP Rep. Brad Wenstrup of Ohio, a doctor, told CNN that while the treatments were legal, â€œI donâ€™t prefer it in my family. In my family, we had a son and then adopted a daughter.â€ GOP Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks of Iowa became the latest Republican to introduce a pro-IVF bill last week. Miller-Meeks said the legislation, which would provide a fully refundable tax credit up to $30,000 for IVF expenses, stemmed from ongoing conversations with other Republican women that picked up over the summer. â€œWe have bantered back and forth,â€ Miller-Meeks told CNN. â€œWe have talked about legislation. And so finally, for me, it was, Iâ€™m tired of hearing criticism from the other side of the aisle on something that we support, and the majority of Americans support, and so weâ€™re going to put forth legislation.â€ A flurry of other bills and resolutions have been introduced, many in the wake of the Alabama Supreme Court ruling, that range in effectiveness and policy goals. Democratic Rep. Susan Wild of Pennsylvania led a bill to codify an individualâ€™s right to IVF access in January. Wild had been searching for a Republican cosponsor in 2023 to introduce the bill, but did not get any Republican support until after the Alabama ruling, a source familiar with the process told CNN. There are now four Republican cosponsors, out of 202 cosponsors, but none of them signed on to Wildâ€™s attempt in July to bypass Republican leadership and force a floor vote. Most of the Republican-led efforts in the House, including from Republican Reps. Lori Chavez-DeRemer of Oregon and Nancy Mace of South Carolina, are largely symbolic non-binding resolutions that express support for IVF. GOP Rep. Zach Nunn of Iowa introduced a bipartisan bill with Wild to protect access to fertility treatments. â€œI feel very strongly about this,â€ Nunn, who has talked to House GOP leadership about his bill, told CNN. â€œThis is the right move forward. Look, regardless of party, coverage for IVF or starting a family is something that every American should be able to pursue.â€ Responding to the other efforts to support IVF in the House, Wild told CNN, â€œI invite all my colleagues, Democrat or Republican, who claim to support IVF to put their money where their mouth is, cosponsor my bill and sign the discharge petition to force a vote on the floor.â€ Rank-and-file members across the conference, not just in swing districts, agreed that voting on pro-IVF legislation, particularly before the election, would be beneficial to Republicans. â€œI think it will help the party immensely, you know, to go on the record,â€ GOP Rep. Ronny Jackson of Texas told CNN. GOP Rep. Cory Mills of Florida echoed: â€œI think it is an important vote. I think it shows our stance.â€ But others, even those who support IVF, donâ€™t see the need for Republicans to force any sort of vote on it and argue that forcing a vote before the election would simply be playing politics. â€œI still donâ€™t even understand why weâ€™re being asked about do Republicans support IVF,â€ GOP Rep. Byron Donalds of Florida said. GOP Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, who supports IVF, poured cold water on the idea that Republicans could vote on any type of IVF legislation before the election, particularly given their current government funding predicament: â€œWe canâ€™t even do anything right now.â€

Title: Both parties court Navajo voters in battleground Arizona | CNN Politics
Content: Nearing the end of the annual Navajo Nation parade route last Saturday, the Arizona Republican Partyâ€™s float â€” pulled by an 18-wheeler and adorned with Trump-Vance campaign signs â€” came to a halt. Some parade watchers, who lined Highway 264 with their lawn chairs, began booing. â€œGet out of here,â€ one woman shouted. President Joe Biden won Arizona by just 10,000 votes â€“ the first Democrat to do so since 1996 â€“ and the state is once again a key battleground this year with Vice President Kamala Harrisâ€™ ascendance on the ticket seen as putting it back in play for Democrats. The Navajo Nation makes up the largest tribe in Arizona, with about 131,000 members, according to the US Census. The presence of both parties at Saturdayâ€™s parade underscored the electoral importance of those tribe members, who could help make a difference not just in the race for the White House in Arizona, but in a key US Senate race that will shape the balance of power in Washington next year. For the first time in its history, the Arizona GOP set up a field office in Window Rock, the capital of Navajo Nation, according to state GOP chair Gina Swoboda. And last Sunday, the state party, along with the Trump campaign and Republican National Committee, hosted another field office opening in Flagstaff. â€œDemocrats are very comfortable that they own this vote bloc,â€ Swoboda told CNN after the parade. â€œAnd no one owns anybody, and no one has the right to expect your vote. They have to earn your vote.â€ Asked about the GOPâ€™s reception at the parade, Swoboda said that itâ€™s â€œimportant to not let that dissuade youâ€ and that the Republican Party needs to be present in the community. â€œIf the Nation itself said we donâ€™t want you, that would be different. â€¦ I feel that itâ€™s urgent to do the outreach, and weâ€™re not going to stop. As long as we are welcome, we will continue to be here,â€ she said, adding that â€œthereâ€™s no vote that Iâ€™m going to leave on the table.â€ But the Harris campaign in Arizona says itâ€™s not taking any votes for granted. It opened a field office in northeast Apache Junction, closer to several reservations, plans to spend on media campaigns in both English and in the Navajo language on Tribal radio, and hold early vote events in the Navajo community. The campaign also walked the Navajo Nation parade route last weekend, which ran more than three miles long, with its float featuring a sign that read â€œskoden voteâ€ â€” Indigenous slang for â€œletâ€™s go then.â€ Highlighting the stakes of the vote here, both Senate candidates â€“ Democratic Rep. Ruben Gallego and GOP nominee Kari Lake â€“ joined the parade, greeting and shaking hands with attendees as part of their outreach to Indigenous voters. The area congressional districtâ€™s candidates â€“ GOP Rep. Eli Crane and his Democratic challenger, former Navajo Nation President Jonathan Nez, attended too, although the district is not seen as competitive this fall. In one of the most crucial Senate races in the country, Lake and Gallego are vying to replace retiring independent Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, who still caucuses with Democrats. Defending her seat is a priority for Democrats looking to hold onto their narrow Senate majority. This summer, Lake â€“ who lost a 2022 gubernatorial bid â€“ toured the Navajo Nation Museum, met with voters at the fairgrounds and visited the Navajo Code Talker Memorial with Navajo Nationâ€™s former Vice President Myron Lizer, according to her campaign. Gallego, who is attempting to visit all of Arizonaâ€™s 22 federally recognized tribes, told CNN that heâ€™s working to get the Native American population out to vote. â€œDemocrats and Republicans donâ€™t actually go and talk to our Tribal leadership, citizens â€” see what they actually need.
